results.title: The Rivers
results.creator_credit: Trevor Ling, Nina Syme and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Victoria the Garden State”.
Since the Industrial Revolution Western man has harnessed rivers to his needs as a producer. By an historical co-incidence the ravages of industrialisation by-pass most of the 13,750 miles of rivers in Victoria.

group_works.title: The Invisible disability: hearing impairment

results.title: The Invisible disability: hearing impairment
results.creator_credit: Alan Foley, Des Pickering and Burwood State College Special Education Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Victoria College Special Education Films”.
Hearing impairment is a common disability amongst the community and this documentary aims to make people more aware of this disability. The causes of deafness are discussed and the program stresses the importance of early detection, as language and speech development are seriously affected if help is delayed. Children and parents discuss their problems with communication. Narrated by Barry McQueen.

results.title: Carronbank: Deaf Blind Education
results.creator_credit: Francis Treacey, Des Pickering and Victoria College (Melbourne, Vic.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Victoria College Special Education Films”.
A documentary that looks at the education of children with visual and hearing impairment. A very important early stage of education is to teach the children how to communicate and the teachers at Carronbank discuss how this is done. The curriculums, at Carronbank, cater for all needs, including social skills as well as the educational requirements.

results.title: The Present from Gondwanaland
results.creator_credit: Mike Weatherley and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
Two hundred million years ago the giant continent Gondwanaland split and Australia drifted away. Its plants and animals evolved in isolation from the rest of the world. How does a tree used as a prison fit into the story and what are the secrets of the gum tree’s success? Narrated by David Bellamy.

results.title: Not so much a desert, more a way of life
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
Much of the surface of Australia is described as desert. But is this a true description? Wherever he looks, David Bellamy finds life among the sand and rocks.

results.title: The Landscape architects
results.creator_credit: Mike Weatherley and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
Australia owes a great debt to the Aboriginals who learned to tame the inhospitable countryside. But why did they never become farmers and what sort of diet did the first Australians enjoy? David Bellamy attempts to find out the answers to these questions.

results.title: The Great Barriers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
Australia’s coasts are battleground’s where seaweeds, coral and mangroves fight for survival against the ravages of the ocean - a survival that is vital to the protection of the coast.
